diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including acute pericarditis, psychosis, thrombocytopenia, fever, and proteinuria, reflecting multisystem involvement.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections, such as those caused by Coxsackievirus or HIV, can lead to symptoms like acute pericarditis, fever, and could potentially cause thrombocytopenia as part of a broader immune response.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.rationale: Rheumatic fever, a complication of Streptococcal throat infection, can manifest with fever, acute pericarditis as part of carditis, and can cause other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD combines features of several autoimmune diseases, including SLE, and can present with fever, thrombocytopenia, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder is characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy morbidity in the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. It can present with thrombocytopenia and might have manifestations like pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: This systemic granulomatous disease can affect any organ, most commonly the lungs, skin, or lymph nodes, but can also involve the heart (as pericarditis), kidneys (proteinuria), and can present with fever.

diagnoses.name: Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: While not typically associated with psychosis, infectious endocarditis can present with fever, heart involvement (though more commonly affecting the valves than the pericardium), thrombocytopenia, and potentially proteinuria due to kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Similar to SLE, drug-induced lupus can present with systemic symptoms including pericarditis, fever, and possibly thrombocytopenia or neuropsychiatric manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis (HLH)
diagnoses.rationale: An aggressive, life-threatening syndrome of excessive immune activation, HLH can present with fever, thrombocytopenia, and evidence of multi-organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Tumor Lysis Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Most commonly seen after the initiation of cancer treatment, it can cause acute kidney failure (with proteinuria), fever, and thrombocytopenia due to the sudden release of intracellular ions and metabolites.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (and other primary psychotic disorders, considering medical causes first)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (especially oral carcinoma in the context of leukoplakia)
Gastrointestinal disorders (as a secondary symptom from primary immune dysfunction or malignancy)

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels of clotting protein in the blood.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body tissues, including the skin, joints, and organs.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, leading to aneurysms and other cardiovascular abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose).

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the thyroid gland, which can impact energy level and metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells, which can lead to blood clots.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes abnormal growth or development of cells in the walls of blood vessels, which can lead to aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues.

diagnoses.name: Hemophilia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your blood doesn't clot normally because it lacks sufficient blood-clotting proteins.

Dysfunction of the urinary bladder due to disease of the central nervous system or peripheral nerves involved in the control of micturition (urination). This can sometimes lead to a combination of urinary tract infections and symptoms affecting the nervous system such as seizure disorders.

A condition in which the kidneys lose the ability to remove waste and balance fluids. This can lead to a variety of symptoms including urinary tract infections and an electrolyte imbalance, which might contribute to seizure disorders.

A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can lead to a wide range of symptoms including neurogenic bladder (leading to urinary tract infections) and seizure disorders.

A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). Diabetes can lead to several complications such as urinary tract infections and neuropathy, which can indirectly contribute to seizures.

A condition in which the blood pressure in the arteries is persistently elevated. Long-standing high blood pressure can lead to damage of various organs including the kidneys, which can increase the risk of urinary tract infections and can contribute to conditions causing seizure disorders.

An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage throughout the body, including in the nervous system and kidneys, potentially leading to both seizure disorders and urinary tract infections.

Hard deposits made of minerals and salts that form inside your kidneys. They can cause urine blockage leading to urinary tract infections. The pain and stress from kidney stones can potentially trigger seizures in predisposed individuals.

A disorder of the inner ear that causes episodes in which you feel as if you're spinning (vertigo), and you have fluctuating hearing loss with a progressive, ultimately permanent loss of hearing, tinnitus is also a common symptom.

Infections that can affect the nose, throat, and sinuses. While primarily affecting the respiratory tract, some severe infections can lead to systemic symptoms. Epistaxis (nosebleeds) may be a related symptom.

Cancer that develops in the tissues of the mouth or throat. It's categorized by the type of cell where it occurs. Leukoplakia can be a precursor lesion to oral cancer. Symptoms can range widely depending on the specific location and stage of the cancer.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Hyperglycemia is a hallmark of diabetes. While diabetes doesn't directly cause hyperthyroidism, the two conditions can coexist, especially in autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This is an autoimmune disease that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism). Graves' disease might indirectly influence glucose levels and skin health.

diagnoses.name: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disorder that can present initially with hyperthyroidism before transitioning to hypothyroidism. Hashimoto’s thyroiditis could be associated with other autoimmune conditions that affect blood sugar levels and skin health.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain types of lymphoma can cause lymphadenitis, basophilia, and affect the thyroid gland. They might also cause systemic symptoms like skin changes (xerosis) and impact metabolic processes affecting glucose levels.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.reasoning: CML is characterized by an increased number of basophils and can also affect glucose metabolism. While not directly linked to hyperthyroidism, systemic effects can impact various bodily functions.

diagnoses.name: Type 2 Diabetes with Thyroid Dysfunction
diagnoses.reasoning: A condition in which hyperglycemia is a primary concern, and thyroid dysfunction can occur as a comorbid condition, impacting metabolism and possibly leading to skin conditions like xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune condition that primarily affects moisture-producing glands leading to xerosis. It can also be associated with other autoimmune conditions affecting the thyroid and potentially impacting blood sugar control.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily a skin condition leading to xerosis, people with atopic dermatitis may have an increased risk of developing autoimmune diseases including thyroid disorders and Type 1 diabetes (associated with hyperglycemia).

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: These disorders can lead to lymphadenitis and have associations with autoimmune conditions that might affect the thyroid and glucose metabolism.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Though primarily characterized by high levels of eosinophils rather than basophils, this rare disorder can have systemic effects, including skin manifestations, thyroid dysregulation, and potentially impacting glucose metabolism.

diagnoses: Bacterial Infections (e.g., Bartonella henselae causing Cat Scratch Disease)
Neurological disorders (e.g., Multiple Sclerosis, Parkinson's Disease)
Psychiatric conditions (e.g., Bipolar Disorder, Anxiety Disorder with physical manifestations)
Blood clotting disorders (e.g., Hemophilia, Vitamin K deficiency)

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, potentially leading to aneurysms, osteopenia, and other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition causing vascular inflammation, which might lead to aneurysms, and can be associated with lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A common chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and easily triggered bronchospasms manifesting as wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. It can result in wheezing and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can lead to aneurysms and osteopenia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes. These cells are in the lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and other parts of the body. It can cause lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection mainly affecting the lungs but can also affect lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), leading to symptoms including wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing or periods of shallow breathing during sleep. It can lead to frequent waking.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that causes vasculitis, which can lead to aneurysms and wheezing due to its effect on the lungs.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, potentially leading to conditions like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses: Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal Infections (PANDAS)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: An intestinal infection marked by diarrhea, cramps, nausea, vomiting, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Food Poisoning
diagnoses.description: An illness caused by eating contaminated food. Its symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Heat Exhaustion
diagnoses.description: A condition whose symptoms may include heavy sweating and a rapid pulse, a result of your body overheating. It's one of three heat-related syndromes, with heat cramps being the mildest and heatstroke being the most severe. Symptoms also include weakness, nausea, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Symptoms can include headaches, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, balance problems, personality or behavior changes, seizures, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include headache, alteration of consciousness, weakness, and numbness, especially on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck. Most cases of meningitis are caused by a viral infection, but bacterial, parasitic, and fungal infections are other causes.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions. If you don't replace lost fluids, you will get dehydrated. Symptoms can include extreme thirst, weakness, headache, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a very low level of blood sugar (glucose), your body's main energy source. Hypoglycemia is often related to the treatment of diabetes. However, a variety of conditions, many of them rare, can cause low blood sugar in people without diabetes. Symptoms include headache, weakness, shaking, nausea, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms can include fatigue, numbness, weakness, dizziness, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light or sound. In some cases, aura such as visual disturbances or numbness may precede the headache.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition occurring when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include headache, numbness, confusion, trouble speaking, and loss of balance or coordination.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease of the central nervous system where the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body. Symptoms can include numbness, weakness, balance issues, and difficulty in coordination (ataxia).

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Symptoms can include headaches, numbness, nausea, and difficulties with coordination.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms can mirror those of a stroke, including numbness and difficulty with balance and coordination.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting the vestibular nerve in the inner ear responsible for balance. It can lead to sudden, severe vertigo (a spinning sensation), difficulty with balance, nausea, and sometimes headache and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord (meninges). Can be caused by viruses, bacteria, or other microorganisms. Symptoms can include headache, fever, neck stiffness, nausea, and in some cases, numbness or altered consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually leading to paralysis. Some cases may include numbness, coordination problems, and difficulty walking.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from a reduced blood flow to the back part of the brain, which is supplied by the vertebral and basilar arteries. Symptoms can include dizziness, vision problems, difficulty walking (ataxia), nausea, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Migrainous Infarction
diagnoses.description: A rare type of ischemic stroke occurring during a migraine with aura attack. The symptoms typically include a severe headache, along with visual disturbances, numbness or weakness, nausea, and problems with speech, balance, and coordination.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (such as scintillation, photophobia) and other neurological symptoms before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it temporarily blocks blood flow to the brain, causing symptoms similar to a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing brain tissue to be damaged.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A type of motor neuron disease that causes the death of neurons controlling voluntary muscles, potentially affecting speech and swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare neurological disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks part of its peripheral nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Multiple System Atrophy
diagnoses.description: A progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting movement, blood pressure, and other body functions.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which worsen after periods of activity and improve after periods of rest.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain; its symptoms can vary greatly depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, spread by ticks. Neurological symptoms can occur in late-stage Lyme disease.

diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus (for peripheral neuropathy with secondary complications)
Vasculitis associated with Hepatitis B or C

diagnoses.name: Lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide array of skin manifestations, including nonscarring alopecia, nasal ulcers, and postinflammatory dyspigmentation. Telangiectasias may also be present, and systemic involvement can lead to neurological symptoms such as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease known for its distinctive skin rash, muscle weakness, and systemic features. Telangiectasias and postinflammatory dyspigmentation can occur. Though muscle and skin are primarily affected, it can also involve other systems, potentially leading to symptoms such as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause skin and connective tissue tightening and thickening. Telangiectasias are common, and postinflammatory dyspigmentation may occur. In advanced cases, systemic involvement can lead to neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in multiple organs, including the skin and mucous membranes, potentially leading to nonscarring alopecia and nasal ulcers. Neurosarcoidosis can cause neurological manifestations like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that involve inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause skin changes such as postinflammatory dyspigmentation and telangiectasias, along with systemic symptoms including neurological effects like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, leading to symptoms ranging from mouth and genital ulcers to more severe complications such as neurological issues.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: An uncommon disorder that causes vasculitis of the small and medium-sized vessels, which can lead to nasal ulcers and systemic symptoms. Neurological involvement can result in symptoms like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by inflammation of small blood vessels, leading to skin changes and potentially systemic symptoms if the CNS is involved.

diagnoses.name: Rosacea
diagnoses.description: A chronic skin condition that causes redness and visible blood vessels in your face (telangiectasias), and may also produce small, red, pus-filled bumps. While not typically associated with systemic symptoms like delirium, it can be severe in some cases.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A more severe form of lupus that can affect any part of the body, including the skin, joints, and organs. Skin manifestations may include nonscarring alopecia, nasal ulcers, and postinflammatory dyspigmentation, while systemic involvement can cause neurological symptoms such as delirium.
